script.text:
Each side, of course, has its own argument about why they're right to do what they're doing.
The open office fans will tell you that it fosters collaboration and creativity among coworkers by allowing them to work together in close proximity with one another.
They'll also remind you that the word "office" literally means "a place where people who don't like each other go." So there's some science behind this shit.
script.cons: Muddled transition from previous component, unclear purpose within overall narrative structure.

script.text: And then, of course, we have the haters, which include myself because I've never met anyone who liked an open office more than me when I was trying to take a nap at my desk at noon every day. But even those haters would argue, all right? Even us haters would say that if we were going to try something new like open offices again, here's how we'd fix it. We'd make sure everyone had their own private space or cubicle or whatever you want to call it, but just give them their own room so no one can bother you. And if you didn't know someone else is bothering you based solely off of sound alone, come up with a noise-cancelling headset for free. That's not too much to ask. You could charge $50 bucks for it. It wouldn't be weird. If anything, the person wearing headphones in public should get paid extra money as well. They shouldn't only listen to music while walking around outside either.

And if you didn't know someone else is bothering you based solely off of sound alone, come up with a noise-cancelling headset for free. That's not too much to ask. You could charge $50 bucks for it. It wouldn't be weird. If anything, the person wearing headphones in public should get paid extra money as well. They shouldn't only listen to music while walking around outside either.
script.pros: Joke craft is strong, Originality is high.
script.cons: Muddled transition from previous idea, Timing/Pacing feels rushed.

script.text: (Setup) The person wearing headphones in public should get paid extra money as well. They shouldn't only listen to music while walking around outside either. What kind of sick bitch does that? No! Maybe you catch the bus early enough before rush hour starts to put on your favorite podcast. Or maybe you got up way earlier than any normal human being should ever wake up from sleep, and now you enjoy listening to audio books. Whatever the case may be, you deserve a bonus, man. A little extra scratch in your pocket for blocking out the rest of society during your daily commute. Right? Give it to him.

(Setup) Now you might think, okay, fine. Bonus for the guy rocking his Beats By Dre in the park. Yeah, yeah. There's always gonna be exceptions to these rules. People wear headsets everywhere for legitimate reasons. Like I said, podcasts, audiobooks. Sometimes they play video games when they walk home late at night after working double shifts. But let's face facts fellas. Most guys rockin' headphones in public aren't listening to Jack Reacher. Right?
script.pros: Familiar tone, good pacing, strong delivery.

script.text: (Setup) Let's face facts, fellas. Most guys rockin' headphones in public ain't listening to Jack Reacher. Hell, half the time when you see somebody walking down the street jamming out to their iPod, they probably lost both of their parents in Hurricane Katrina. Then they went through the whole ordeal of living in a FEMA trailer without a roof over their heads and now they can't help but hum their least favorite Katy Perry song whenever it rains. Just saying.

script.cons: Some parts feel disconnected from the rest of the story, making it hard to follow

script.text: (Setup) Oh boy, oh boy. Okay, look, let me start this off by saying that I'm originally from Los Angeles, California, which is great. Thank you very much. Great city, beautiful weather year round, wonderful beaches, amazing restaurants. Everything I need to live happily ever after for the rest of my life except for one thing: traffic. God damn it. Man. I hate traffic in LA more than I love sunshine. Which doesn't mean a lot because I absolutely adore sunshine. But traffic is ridiculous.

(Setup) My friends back East complain about potholes and shoveling snow. I'm like, hey dude, drive three miles south and experience paradise. Traffic sucks, man. Not only does it suck for me personally, driving around LA getting honked at, almost hitting pedestrians, and losing my mind every single day. But it really hurts the economy as well, according to studies done recently. Because if you spend more than two hours stuck in traffic per week, chances are good that you won't feel motivated to buy stuff later in the evening when you finally arrive at your destination. Got to prioritize self-care first, baby. Prioritize yourself. Get yourself a bowl of ramen noodles. Watch Game of Thrones reruns until midnight.

(Setup) In fact, according to this study, women actually tend to shop more often than men, especially if they ride the train into Manhattan during peak hours. But I guess if you add up all the minutes spent commuting across America for both sexes combined, men still end up buying less crap overall because we refuse to stop moving forward towards our goals unless absolutely necessary. We don't believe in taking naps mid-afternoon.

(Setup) Look, obviously, uh... We're not lazy, ladies. Obviously. I wasn't born yesterday. All right. Listen, we all agree that feminism is important. Yes. Please clap along, sisters. Equality for all genders. Absolutely.

(Setup) (Setup) However, I am starting to notice lately that sometimes, you know, dudes in feminist spaces will talk about feminism using terms that seem perfectly harmless to them, but somehow misogynistic to everybody else. For example, you know how white people will use phrases like racial reconciliation, racial healing, reparations for slavery, voting rights act, black lives matter? Never once heard a male feminist say that. Only females talking about feminism. Men rarely discuss gender equality amongst themselves, unfortunately. When I bring this topic up with fellow dudes, I hear responses such as, oh, bro, we gotta support sisterhood, you know? You gotta lift her up. She's carrying the load. Women's rights are human rights. Don't shoot the messenger.
script.cons: somewhat predictable punchline, lackluster callback potential.
